description: As decypher, but not retaining the y from the Old French etyma of cipher (cyfre, cyffre); the i spelling tends to be preferred etymologically, being consistent with its cognates, the French déchiffrer and the Italian decifrare, and with their common ancestor, the Medieval Latin cifra, cifera, ciphra.

examples: I enclose a letter which I received yesterday evening from the Marques de Monsalud, containing the decipher of a letter from the King to the Comte d'Erlon. I wish that the Marques had sent the ciphered letter here  […]

verbs.description: decipher (third-person singular simple present deciphers, present participle deciphering, simple past and past participle deciphered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To decode or decrypt a code or cipher to plain text.
(transitive) To read text that is almost illegible or obscure
(transitive) To make sense of a complex situation.
(transitive) To find a solution to a problem.
